To increase her clothing production, she wants to use this loan to buy fabrics and thread. In the future, Miriam wants to have her sewing workshop completed so that she can provide work to other people.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase fabrics and thread

loans.name: Melva Aidee

texts.es:
En la Ciudadela Comercio de la Ciudad de Portoviejo. Ciudad de los Reales Tamarindos, se reúnen cada 15 días las socias del  Banco Comunal Mujeres Solidarias Exitosas.

Nos sentamos a dialogar con la señora Melva, es madre soltera tiene 5 hijos, dos de los cuales viven con ella.

Dice que su vida ha sido muy difícil ya que no tiene casa propia, vive en una casa que le prestó su hermana, pero desde que ingreso al Banco  Comunal las cosas han ido cambiando. Cuando recibió el primer crédito puso un negocio de venta de pescado el mismo que lo sigue manteniendo.
 
Se levanta todos los días de madrugada para comprar el pescado fresco, “que es el mejor” después su hijo sale a recorrer el campo en una moto porque es allí donde se vende mejor. Su forma de venta es directa y compra lo necesario para que se venda todo ya que cuesta mucho mantener el producto en buen estado hasta el otro día.

Este nuevo crédito lo va a utilizar para comprar más pescado y un congelador para almacenarlo.

Sus sueños son tener su casa propia y un carro para salir a distribuir el pescado.
texts.en:
The Successful Mutually Supportive Women communal bank meets every two weeks in Portoviejo’s Ciudadela Comercio, Ciudad de los Reales Tamarindos. We sat down to chat with Melva. She’s a single mother of five children, two of whom still live with her. She says that her life has been very difficult because she doesn’t own her own house; she lives in a house borrowed from her sister. But, since she joined the communal bank things have been changing. When she got her first loan she set up a business selling fish that she still runs. She gets up every day at dawn to buy fresh fish because “it’s the best.” Later her son goes out on a motorcycle to sell in the countryside because that’s where sales are best. She sells direct and buys only what will be able to sell completely because it is very difficult to keep this product in good condition from one day to the next. This new loan will be used to buy more fish and a freezer to store it in. Her dreams are to own her own house and a car to use to sell fish.

Translated from Spanish by Michael Bujazan, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy fish and a freezer.

loans.name: Kemokai

texts.en:
This is 43-year-old M.. He is married and has two children, ages 10 and 5 years. He has two additional dependents who live with him because they are his sisters-in-law. In the year 2000, M. established a hard rum, soft drinks, engine oil and water business. He started this on a small scale then developed it from the proceeds raised. Working 6 days a week and 9 hours a day, he earns about 2,708,000 leones (SLL) every month from this business. 

M. has a very good loan repayment history. He needs a loan of 4,500,000 SLL. M. has already received and successfully repaid a loan of 3,000,000 and now requires a new loan in order to buy bitter appetizer, bumper gin, pure heaven and bull gin. He hopes that this loan will enable him to increase his monthly profits by approximately 812,400 SLL. M. hope to reinvest the proceeds from this loan into his business and educate his children. He thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To buy more drinks for his stall

loans.name: Dondovdorj

texts.en:
Mr. Dondovdorj, 29, is married and has one daughter, age 14. The daughter attends a local secondary school. They live in their own small wooden house in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. They are planning to renovate their home next summer. 

In 2001 Dondovdorj graduated from an Art College as a craftsman which specialized in traditional Mongolian blacksmithing. Between 2001 and 2003 he worked in an art factory, which provided him with good experience. In 2003 he decided to open his own art workshop and since then his business has been doing quite well. 

His wife, Otgojargal, is a craftsman as well and they run the business together. Dondovdorj was telling us that his business was struggling when they first started, but now they have their own customers from whom they receive enough orders. They make things by customer order and design in a single copy. Therefore customers always remain satisfied and happy. 

At the moment their product size is limited by the size of their oven, which they use for casting and melting the metal. Therefore, they want to use the loan to buy an oven for metalwork with a bigger capacity and capability.

loans.use: to buy an oven for metalwork with a bigger capacity and capability

loans.name: Delia

texts.en:
Delia  E. is a married woman who lives in Hda. Maruja, Brgy.9, Isabela, Negros Occidental. She earns her living by operating one business venture: a bakery.  Her husband Renato E., who is 44 years old, works as a laborer to earn his living, and also helps in his wife's business activity.  They have one child who is 17 years old. 

Delia  joined NWTF-Project Dungganon in 1997 because she aspired for something better for her family. With the help of her past 18 loans from NWTF-Project Dungganon, Delia  has been incrementally lifting her family out of poverty by the sweat of her brow. Her previous loan of PHP 20,000 helped her earn a monthly profit of PHP 10,000, uplifting the family's standard of living.  This time, for her 19th loan, she is borrowing PHP 22,000, which she intends to use to buy yeast, oil, sugar, margarine, etc. so that she can continue to save up for future tuition for her children and for house repair. 

Delia  E. is a Dungganon woman who is following an honorable path toward the achievement of her dreams.

 About NWTF: 

In a world full of challenges, Negros Women for Tomorrow Foundation (NWTF), is making a difference in the lives of thousands of women through Project Dungganon (a Hiligaynon word that means Honorable). Through the alleviation program, NWTF is empowering these women to progress from earning less than $1 a day to achieving realities that surpass even their dreams. They have taken a life path that will ultimately make them Dungganon - a title of esteem that is bestowed on a member of a community who has earned the respect through a lifetime of hard and honest work. Help NWTF continue its mission to help the poorest in the Philippines by clicking  the link to the   NWTF Kiva lending team  on Kiva.org to join our team.

loans.use: Fund the operations of bakery

loans.name: Jargalsaihan

texts.en:
Jargalsaihan L. is 37 years old and lives with her husband and two daughters in a house with a fence in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Her husband operates a taxi service as well as a carpentry business to support his family, while her older daughter attends the local high school. Jargalsaihan is a diligent, optimistic and hardworking woman.

Jargalsaihan sells fruit at retail from a rented mobile stall in the local market. She started her business in 2002 and has gained much experience since then. She halted business for three months after having a baby in 2009, but today her business carries on as a stable operation.

Jargalsaihan is requesting a 3,000,000 MNT loan in order to purchase more fruit for her fruit business and necessary wood and supplies for her husband's carpentry business.

loans.use: To buy more fruit and wood

loans.name: Leonisa

texts.en:
Leonisa D. is from the village of Malibangcao Clarin Misamis Occidental. She is 42 years old, married, and has five school-aged children. To make a living, Leonisa cooks and sells food. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from preparing and selling cooked food for daily meals. Leonisa has been engaged in her business for over 20 years and earns approximately 4,000 PHP a month.

In 2004, Leonisa joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Leonisa has successfully repaid a previous loan of 7,000 PHP from GDMPC. Leonisa is requesting a new loan of 10,000 PHP, which will be used to invest in expanding the business. This loan will be Leonisa's ninth loan from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three units offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherpeople, and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To invest in expanding the business

loans.name: Rebeca Josefina

texts.es:
La Señora Rebeca L. es socia del banco comunal Nuevas Amigas, vive en la comunidad El Amarillo en la parroquia de Cumbe. La parroquia de San Luís de Cumbe se encuentra situada al sureste de la ciudad de Cuenca, su artesanía se basa en tejidos, bordados e hilado de lana de oveja confeccionando la vestimenta de la región, su gente se dedica a la agricultura y ganadería.

Nuestra socia tiene 35 años, es casada y tiene 2 hijos 14 y 12 años de edad que estudian en un colegio de la ciudad. Su esposo labora en el área de la construcción ya que es albañil, gracias a la comprensión, trabajo y esfuerzo conyugal han logrado construir su casa propia.

Doña Rosa se dedica a los quehaceres de su hogar y al cuidado de sus hijos, en su casa aprovecha para dedicarse a la cría de ganado, vende la leche a los carros lecheros que circulan por el sector.

Se encuentra en su treceavo crédito que realiza en el banco comunal,  le gusta  por se encuentra con sus amigas con quienes conversa y se ríe saliendo de su rutina diaria. El nuevo crédito que realiza lo va a invertir en la compra de una vaca. Su sueño es ya no tener deudas.
texts.en:
Rebeca L. is a member of the “Nuevas Amigas” (New Friends) community bank.  She lives in El Amarillo community, in Cumbe parish.  San Luís de Cumbe parish is in the south-east of the city of Cuenca.  The region's handicrafts are based on weavings, embroideries and sheep's wool yarn.  These are used to make the region's traditional clothing.  The people work in farming and raising livestock.

Rebeca is 35 years old.  She is married and has 2 children aged 14 and 12 who are both at school in the city.  Her husband works is a construction worker.  Thanks to their joint understanding, work and effort, they have managed to build their own home.

Rebecca does her housework and looks after her children.  She also raises cattle and sells their milk to the milk trucks which come to the district.

This is Rebeca's thirteenth loan through her community bank.  She likes her community bank because she meets up with her friends, chats to them and has a laugh, leaving her daily routine at the door.  This new loan will be invested in buying a cow.  Her dream is to have no debt.

loans.use: To buy a cow

loans.name: Rosy Janet

texts.es:
Rosy es una madre de familia de 37 años de edad que reside junto a su esposo y a sus hijos en el distrito de Jayanca, una zona agrícola que se encuentra ubicada en la provincia de Lambayeque, a más de una hora de la ciudad de Chiclayo.

Ella cuenta con establecimiento en su domicilio en donde suele ofrecer todo tipo de artículos de uso personal, como prendas de vestir, cosméticos y accesorios. El negocio ya tiene una antigüedad de cinco años y durante este tiempo se ha vuelto bastante conocida, actualmente cuenta con una clientela fiel. Los ingresos que percibe de estas actividades los utiliza para ayudar a su esposo a solventar los gastos económicos de su familia.

Rosy desea ampliar su negocio adquiriendo más productos de modo que pueda satisfacer la demanda que suele incrementarse durante la temporada navideña. Por ello ha creído conveniente solicitar a Edpyme Alternativa un crédito de 2000 nuevos soles.
texts.en:
Rosy, 37, is a mother living with her husband and children in Jayanca district, a farming zone located in Lambayeque province, over an hour from the city of Chiclayo.

She has an establishment in her house where she tends to sell all kinds of items for personal use like: clothing, cosmetics and accessories.  The store has been in business for five years and has become quite well known in this time; she can now count on a regular clientele.  She uses income from sales to help her husband meet family expenses.

Rosy would like to expand the business acquiring more products so that she can meet demand that tends to increase during the Christmas season.  She has, therefore, asked Edpyme Alternativa for a 2000 new sol loan.

loans.use: To buy stock items for her store.

loans.name: Anonymous

texts.en:
This Kiva borrower is a 35-year-old single woman from Lebanon. She lives with her parents and 5 siblings. She cooperates with her sister to provide the needed family income. She began working in a locA. hospitA. as a secretary 15 years. In parallel, she decided in 2008 to work as an esthetician and do women's hairdressing. She purchases her products from a locA. beauty center. She works in her domicile and sometimes at her client’s house, depending on their requests. It’s frequent in Lebanon to have severA. jobs to increase profitability and attain higher standards of living.

Today, she is requesting to borrow $1200 from Kiva partner Ameen s.a.l to purchase additionA. products and needed tools to develop her beauty occupation and be able to offer better service.

loans.use: to purchase additional products

loans.name: Lissette Rafaela

texts.es:
En el sector conocido como el Cadí de  la ciudad de Portoviejo, capital de Manabí conocida desde hace muchos años  como la ciudad de los reales tamarindos, se reúnen cada quince días  las socias del Banco Comunal Juntas Creceremos, este lugar es muy hermoso y las personas muy agradables.

Aquí conocimos a la señora Lissette,  tiene 33 años y mantiene una relación de unión libre de la cual tiene una hermosa bebita de 3 meses.  Su marido es Ing. Industrial pero no ejerce su profesión por el momento, ella es egresada de secretariado ejecutivo.

Ellos tienen una tienda de viveras de consumo en la casa de sus padres en la cual venden productos como arroz, azúcar, aceites, detergentes, trabajan todos los días desde las 6am hasta las 22h00 y a veces hasta más tarde, los productos las compras en el centro de Portoviejo aunque la mayoría de sus productos los recibe en su local. Nos cuenta que tienen este negocio ya por 14 años y que gracias a Dios le ha dado para salir adelante.

Este crédito lo va a emplear en surtir mas su tienda, va a comprar arroz, azúcar, aceite, detergentes, embutidos y otros productos de primera necesidad. Está en el Banco Comunal hace tres ciclos  y le gusta porque ha hecho más amigas en el grupo. Sus sueños son tener su casa propia y que su tienda crezca cada día más.
texts.en:
In the Cadí section of the city of Portoviejo, capital of Manabí, known for many years as the City of the Royal Tamarinds, the members of the Juntas Creceremos (Together We Will Grow) communal bank meet every two weeks.  This is a very beautiful place and the people are very likeable.

We met Lissette, 33, here.  She’s in a common law relationship and has a beautiful, 3 month old, baby girl.  Her husband is an Industrial Engineer but he does not practice his profession for the moment.  She graduated as an Executive Secretary.

They have a grocery store in her parents’ house where they sell products like: rice, sugar, oils and detergents.  They work every day from 6am until 10pm and sometimes even later.  She buys her products in Portoviejo although most are delivered to her store.  She tells us that they’ve had this business for 14 years and, thanks be to God, it’s produced enough for them to get ahead.

This loan will be used to better stock the store.  She will buy rice, sugar, oil, detergents, cured meats and other basic need items.  She has been in the communal bank for three cycles and she likes it because she has made more friendships in the group.  Her dreams are to have a house of her own and that her store grows more every day.

loans.use: To buy rice, sugar, oil, detergent, cured meats and other basic need items.

loans.name: Felix Benjamin

texts.es: SOLICITANTE TIENE 25 AÑOS ES CONVIVIENTE VIVE EN CASA DE SUS SUEGROS TIENE UNA MENOR HIJA DE 3 AÑOS SE DEDICA AL SERVICIO DE TRANSPORTE ALQUILA EL CARRO DE SUS SUEGROS CONYUGE SE DEDICA ALA VENTA DE PRODUCTOS DE BELLEZA PERO NO LE A CONSIDERADO EN LA EVALUACION YA QUE NO CUENTA CON LAS ULTIMAS GUIAS, SOLICITAN EL CREDITO PARA GASTOS PERSONALES, CUENTAN CON BUENAS REFERENCIAS PERSONALES REGULAR ACUMULACION DE BIENES, SE LES PROPONE CREDITO SIN GARANTIA DE CASA POR CONTAR CON VOLUNTAD Y CAPACIDAD DE PAGO.
texts.en:
The applicant is 25 years old and lives with his parents in law.  He has a three year old daughter and runs a taxi service.  He rents the car from his in-laws.  His wife sells beauty products but she was not considered at the time of evaluation since she didn't have the most recent income statement.  

They are requesting a loan to cover personal expenses.  They have good character references and a steady income.  They are being proposed for a loan without using their house as collateral since they are committed and able to pay it back.

loans.use: For personal expenses

loans.name: Dama

texts.en:
Dama is a married woman with three children, one of whom attends school while two are adults. She lives in a rental house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for the family. 

She has operated a charcoal selling business for the past five years, selling in a shop to her neighbours. Dama faces a major challenge of seasonality and high cost of transportation in her business. She hopes to establish more businesses in the future.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase sacks of charcoal for sale. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase sacks of charcoal for sale

loans.name: Primero Dios Group

texts.es:
El grupo Primero Dios está conformado por tres personas trabajadoras una de ellos es Damaso Abba V. Gago, él  junto a sus 5 hijos se dedica a la agricultura desde hace 6 años en especial maíz, frijoles, trigo etc. Con el préstamo el paga el alquiler de las tierras donde cultiva.

Las otras integrantes del grupo son Xiomara H. quien vende chatarra desde hace 2 años y María Luisa M. vende ropa.
texts.en:
The Primero Dios ["God First"] group is made up of three hard-working people. One of them is Damaso Abba V. Gago, who has worked in agriculture for the past 6 years together with his 5 children, especially growing corn, beans, wheat, etc. With the loan, he will pay the rent for the lands he cultivates. 

The other members of the group are Xiomara H., who has sold scrap metal for 2 years, and María Luisa M., who sells clothing.

loans.use: Paying the rent for his farmland

loans.name: Marisol

texts.es:
La Sra. Marisol A., pertenece al Banco Comunal “Las Moralinas”, del Distrito D. Morales, Departamento D. San Martín. Está Casada, tiene 41 años, con estudios secundarios incompletos y es madre D. 04 hijos, todos dependientes D. ella. 

Marisol, es una mujer muy trabajadora y emprendedora lo cual la llevó a incursionar en el negocio D. la  venta D. chupetes (helados D. hielo), ubicando el negocio en su misma casa, en un ambiente muy bien acondicionado y acogedor, para atender a sus clientes, que a día a día la frecuentan.  Nos cuenta que en la actualidad se siente muy contenta, ya que su negocio le está yendo muy bien. Con su primer crédito D. 300 Nuevos Soles  compró frutas, cajas D. leche, azúcar, etc.

Con este préstamo D. S/. 2,000.00 Nuevos Soles comprará ingredientes para la preparación D. sus chupetes  como azúcar en sacos,  cajas D. leche y frutas por kilos, que a diario necesita para la preparación D. los chupetes, así como también gelatinas y helados para venderlos al por mayor. 

Marisol, se siente con mucha fortaleza para continuar trabajando y perseverando día a día. Agradece al Movimiento Manuela Ramos por ayudar a mujeres como ella a tener oportunidades D. desarrollarse.
texts.en:
Marisol A. is a member of the Las Moralinas comunal bank in the Morales district, San Martín department.  She is 41 years old and married.  She did not finish high school.  She has four children, and they are all dependent upon her.

Marisol is a hard-working and enterprising woman.  That is what led her to start her business of selling “chupetes” (frozen pops).  Her business is located in her house in a spot that is well established and welcoming in order to take care of her customers who frequent her business day to day.

She tells us that she is very content now.  Her business is going very well for her.  With her first loan for 300 soles she bought fruit, cases of milk, and sugar, etc.

With this loan for 2,000 soles she will buy ingredients like sacks of sugar, cases of milk, and fruit by the kilo to make her chupetes.  She will also buy gelatin and ice cream to sell wholesale.

Marisol has a lot of fortituD. to continue working and persevering day to day.  She is grateful to the Movimiento Manuela Ramos for helping women like her have an opportunity to grow.

loans.use: to buy ingredients like sacks of sugar, cases of milk, and fruit by the kilo

loans.name: Reang

texts.en:
Mrs. Reang K., 50, is a widow with three children – two sons and one daughter. One of her children is a garment factory worker, one is in university and the other is in high school. The family lives in a suburb about 20 kilometers from Phnom Penh.
Reang has been operating a business renting a part of her house to garment factory workers because her house is located near a garment factory. She is asking for her first loan of $1,200 to pay school fees and buy a computer laptop for her son who is in university.

loans.use: to pay school fees and buy a laptop for her son

loans.name: Lorenzo

texts.es: Lorenzo, de 62 años, es un hombre muy amable y trabajador, vive en su casa propia junto a  su esposa María de 52 años y lo que más desea es trabajar muy duro para vivir una vejez tranquila a lado de su amada pareja. El día de Lorenzo comienza muy temprano por la mañana, cuando abre su puesto y empieza con su venta de pollos, su negocio esta ubicado en el mercado Luciana (Mercado importante del distrito de Carabayllo), él es un vendedor muy persuasivo y siempre logra sacar una sonrisa de sus clientes. Lo que más le gusta de su negocio es conversar con sus vecinas de venta, quienes con sus bromas hacen más alegres las largas jornadas de venta, lleva 30 años en esta actividad y considera que lo más difícil es tener que permanecer todo el día en su puesto de venta. Espera tener en el futuro un emporio donde pueda vender con mayor tranquilidad sus pollos congelados. Este es el cuarto crédito con MFP y se siente feliz de haberlo obtenido, en su banco comunal es un socio muy querido, ya que siempre ayuda en todo lo necesario. Con los dos mil quinientos nuevos soles solicitados, comprará más pollos para cubrir mejor la demanda de sus clientes.
texts.en:
Lorenzo, 62 years old, is a kind, hard-working man who lives in his own home with his wife María who is 52.  He aspires most to working hard now so he can have a peaceful retirement together with his beloved partner.  Lorenzo begins his day very early in the morning to set up his chicken stall in the Luciana Market (an important market in the district of Carabayllo).  He is a very persuasive salesman and always elicits a smile from his customers.

What he enjoys most about his business is talking to his colleagues whose jokes make the long day more enjoyable.  He's been in business for 30 years and believes that the hardest part of his job is having to spend the entire day in one place.  Sometime in the future he would like to have an emporium where he could sell frozen chicken in a calmer environment.  

This is his fourth loan through MFP and he is very grateful for it.  He is a well-loved member of the bank and always helps out there when he can.  He plans to use the 2,500 PEN to buy more chicken to be able to meet customer demand.

loans.use: To buy chickens

loans.name: Enagnon Group

texts.fr:
ENAGNON est un groupe de trois personnes, dont les membres sont des amies qui vendent toutes dans le même marché de Missèbo à Cotonou (Capitale économique du Bénin). Afin d'élever le niveau de leur activité et de faire face à la demande de leur clientèle, ce groupe s'est rapproché de ALIDé, en vue de l'obtention d'un deuxième prêt.
La présidente du groupe, Gérardine (dont la main est levée sur la photo), est née le 22 Avril 1960 à Adjohoun dans le département de l'Ouémé. Gérardine est mariée à Albert et est mère de quatre enfants, tous scolarisés, dont un reste à sa charge. Gérardine s'est installée depuis trente ans à Kpankpan à Cotonou, où elle vit avec son mari et son enfant encore à sa charge. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la maison. Gérardine a arrêté l'école au cours secondaire et a appris ensuite la couture, activité qu'elle exerce depuis une douzaine d'année et qui lui procure des revenus l'aidant à subvenir à ses besoins. Parallèlement à cette activité, Gérardine vend des fiperies au marché de Missèbo à Cotonou. Dans le but de rehausser son activité et de mieux répondre à la demande de plus en plus forte de la clientèle, Gérardine sollicite pour une deuxième fois de crédit auprès de ALIDé. Son ambition est d'avoir plus tard sa propre boutique.
texts.en:
ENAGNON is a group composed of three people, whose members are friends who all sell in the same market in Missèbo in Cotonou, the economic capital of Benin. In order to bolster their businesses and meet customer demand, this group has come to Kiva's partner, ALIDé, to seek a second loan.

The leader of the group, Géraldine (raising her hand in the photograph) was born on April 22, 1960 in Adjohoun, in Ouémé Department. She's married to Albert and is the mother of four children, who all attended school. She still has one child to support. 30 years ago, she moved in to Kpankpan in Cotonou, where she lives with her husband and the child she still supports. The couple takes care of the various household expenses together.

Géraldine dropped out of middle school and learned sewing, an activity she's been doing for about twelve years and from which she draws an income helping her provide for herself. In parallel, she sells used clothing at the Missèbo market in Cotonou. With the goal of bolstering her business and better meeting an ever-increasing customer demand, Géraldine is seeking a second loan from ALIDé. Her ambition is to have her own shop in the future.

loans.use: to buy used clothing

loans.name: Rodora

texts.en:
Rodora D. is from the village of Barangay 2, Talakag, Bukidnon. She is 34 years old, married and has 3 school-aged children. Rodora owns & operates a business making and selling snacks & other delicacies like siopao, binangkal, nilubid & chicken barbecue in the local community. Rodora has been engaged in her business for over 3 years and earns approximately 10,000 PHP a month.

In 2010, Rodora joined HSPFI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 8,000 PHP from HSPFI. This previous loan was used to to purchase additional ingredients & to provide working capital. She is requesting a new loan of 11,000 PHP which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed like flour, eggs, milk & chicken meat. This will be her 3rd loan from HSPFI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated to improve/expand her business. 

About HSPFI:

HSPFI is one of the accredited partners of Opportunity International in the Philippines. It is based in Cagayan de Oro City and is reaching out to the poor households of Northern Mindanao.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, we created this template for our field staff to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients needed like flour, eggs, milk & chicken meat

loans.name: Nancy Amparo

texts.es:
La socia pertenece al banco comunal “SAN JOSE DE URUBAMBA”; El banco está ubicado en el distrito de Urubamba, perteneciente a la provincia de Urubamba y departamento de Cusco.

La socia es la Sra. Nancy Amparo; ella tiene 43 años de edad y es soltera y tiene 4 hijos; La socia alterna sus actividades diarias con el negocio de venta de cubrecamas, sabanas y cortinas, ella vende en forma ambulatoria en el mercado de Urubamba, la socia también trabaja en la municipalidad de Urubamba en el área de almacen,la socia quiere ampliar y mejorar el negocio de venta de cortinas, sabanas y cubrecamas. La socia solicita el préstamo para comprar mercadería de variedad de sabanas, cubrecamas y sabanas.

La socia está feliz por el préstamo y se compromete a cumplir con los pagos de su cuota.
texts.en:
Here is a member of the communal bank "San Jose de Urubamba". It is located in the district of Urubamba, belonging to the province of Urubamba and the department of Cusco. 

Her name is Nancy Amparo. She is 43 years old, single, and she has 4 children. She alternates her daily activities with her business selling comforters, bed sheets, and curtains. She makes her sales itinerantly in the market in Urubamba. She also works in the municipality of Urubamba, in the warehousing sector. She wants to expand and improve her business selling curtains, bed sheets, and bedspreads. She requires a loan to purchase merchandise including a variety of bed sheets, bedspreads and linen.

She is happy for the loan and she is committed to making her loan payments.

loans.use: to purchase a variety of bed sheets, bed spreads, and linen.

loans.name: Jacob

texts.en:
Jacob, who was born in 1956, is married to Eunice Nage and they are blessed with six children, one of whom is younger than 15. They live in a two-room apartment in the Tumuku Belo subdivision. Jacob had a lot of difficulty in providing for his six children, so in 2010 he was introduced to GHAPE by his friend, who was a member. He had his first loan of 50,000 XAF, which he used to purchase goats and to farm.

Jacob is requesting a second loan to buy seven goats for 75,000 XAF, beans for 22,500 XAF and corn for 32,500 XAF. He knows that he will succeed since he has enough land to graze his goats and to farm. Jacob is satisfying the high demand for goats in his community and thus helping the community. He was challenged when his son failed his certificate exam. Jacob will use the profit from this loan to pay his children's tuition fees and to repay his loan. Jacob took a loan from GHAPE because the interest rates are low and repayment is bit by bit. About GHAPE The Grounded and Holistic Approach to People's Empowerment (GHAPE) is a non-profit NGO based in Bamenda, Cameroon. GHAPE works towards the empowerment of the poor and poverty alleviation through a highly multi-faceted approach. Every client is trained in business management, basic health, life skills, financial management, profits and losses, and family values. Clients are also required to contribute a small amount into a personal savings account; most clients save much more than the minimum requirement. GHAPE instils a sense of family and community within its clients and staff and has developed a strong bond of trust between the organization and its clients.

loans.use: to buy seedlings for planting and goats for rearing.

loans.name: Ritchelda

texts.en:
Ritchelda is married with four children. She is 50 years old and lives in ZNAC, Tampilisan. 

To earn a living, Richelda has a snack vending business. She has had this business for 16 years. Each month, she earns approximately PHP 5000. 

Ritchelda has been a member of PMPC for two years.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients for her snack vending business.

loans.name: Youth Tukore Associates Group

texts.en:
Thirty-five-year-old Robert operates a general merchandise retail business in Ntungamo Town. This happily married man's business has been in existence for the past four years. Robert is a father of two, and he says it was the persuasion of one of his closest friends that gave him the motivation to try his hand at this business. Before that, Robert was living only within the means of his low-paying teaching job. He still does teach, notwithstanding the low remuneration.

Robert is a stickler for diligence, and he says the hard work he has put into everything he does has been showing in his success. Weekly he says this retail business generates him profits totaling up to 520,000 Ugandan shillings. This Kiva loan's purpose, he says, is for the purchase of more retail commodities like sugar, salt, plastics, dry beans, rice, maize flour, toothpaste, etc., to resell.

loans.use: to purchase more retail commodities like sugar, salt, rice, dry beans, etc., to resell.

loans.name: Mwanakombo

texts.en:
Mwanakombo is a married woman with eight children, four girls and four boys. She owns a house that has neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expenses are food and school fees.

For the past three years, she has operated a business of buying and selling goats. Her potential customers are neighbors and butcher operators. She faces a major challenge of seasonality in her business. Her major dream is to expand her business in the future.

With the 10,000 KES she wants to purchase six goats and pay for their transport. She decided to join Yehu to access loans to boost her business.

loans.use: To purchase six goats and pay for their transport.

loans.name: Prenadora

texts.en:
Prenadora works hard to support her family. She is single and has a sari-sari (general) store in the Philippines.

Prenadora has requested a PHP 12,000 loan through NWTF to purchase more stock to sell in her store. She has been in this business for three years.

In the future, Prenadora would like to save money to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock for resale.

loans.name: Ivan

texts.es: El señor Ivan es productor lechero y también cría ganado vacuno; la leche que produce la vende directamente a la empresa PIL ANDINA que es una fábrica industrializadora de productos lácteos. El crédito lo requiere para  la compra de un par de vacas lecheras de raza mejorada para mejorar sus ingresos por venta de leche. Ivan y su familia viven en casa de sus padres  ubicada en la localidad de Laja del  departamento de La Paz; es soltero y no tiene hijos. Es la primera vez que obtiene un crédito en IMPRO.
texts.en:
Sr. Ivan is a milk producer and also raises cattle. The milk he produces is sold directly to the PIL Andina Company, which has an industrial factory that processes dairy products. The loan he is requesting will be used to buy a pair of dairy cows of improved breed so that he can increase his revenues from selling milk. Ivan and his parents live in their own home in the town of Laja in the Department of La Paz. He is single and has no children.

This is the first time he has obtained a loan from IMPRO.

loans.use: to buy a pair of dairy cows.

loans.name: Edne

texts.en:
Edne is 29 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. 
Edne has a shop that sells canned goods, snacks & rice by the kilogram. She has had this business for 2 years. She requested a loan of PHP 8,000 to buy stock for her store.
Edne has been a member of HSPFI since 2011. In the future, Edne hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks & beverages

loans.name: 13.75 Thiệu Đô Group

texts.en:
Mrs Thoa operates a food stall selling meat. She is requesting a loan to purchase cattle to butcher to sell meat.

Thoa is 48 years old and she is married with four children. Thoa is the group leader of the 13.75 Thiệu Đô solidarity group, which consists of six members. She lives and works in Thieu Hoa district, a semi-urban area in Thanh Hoa province, with two dependents.

This is Thoa's first loan with Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Thoa has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Thoa faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In future, Thoa hopes for her business to do well, to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business, and for her children to find a good job.

loans.use: to purchase cattle to butcher to sell meat.

loans.name: Luis Fernando

texts.es:
Luis Fernando inició su negocio vendiendo las películas a domicilio y surtiendo de las mismas a diferentes negocios.

Hace 3 años Luis le compra el negocio de alquiler de películas a una amiga que decide viajar a otro país, él aún continua surtiendo a otros negocios y vendiendo a domicilio.

Él quiere mejorar su negocio para así poder mayor clientela y así mejorar su calidad de vida.
texts.en:
Luis began a business of selling home movies and supplying them to various businesses.

Three years ago Luis bought the business from a friend who decided to leave the country. 

He still continues supplying other businesses and selling to homes. He wants to grow the business in order to have more customers and thus improve his quality of life.

loans.use: to purchase location-based media equipment

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en: Sarah is 47 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with 2 children. Sarah has operated a retail shop for 5 years, selling canned goods, snacks and beverages. She has requested a loan of PHP 5,000 to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages. Sarah is a new member of HSPFI.  In the future, Sarah hopes to improve her business.

loans.use: to buy canned goods, snacks and beverages

loans.name: Joseph

texts.en:
Joseph is from the village of Calaocan, Angadanan. He is 40 years old, married, and has five children. Two of his children are still studying. To make a living, Joseph owns & operates a business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting corn for sale. He has been engaged in his business for 20 years and earns approximately 17,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month from these activities.

Now, Joseph is requesting a loan of 30,000 PHP which will be used to purchase seedlings and fertilizer for his business farm. He plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand the business.

loans.use: to purchase seedlings and fertilizer for his business farm.

loans.name: Hovsep

texts.en: Hovsep is from the town of Gyumri in the Shirak region of Armenia.  He is married with three children – two daughters (sixteen and eighteen) and a nine-year-old son.  He has a high school education and has been trained as an auto mechanic.  Previously, he worked in that field.  For the past five years, however, Hovsep has been running a small shop.  It is hard work but he enjoys being a sole entrepreneur.  Hovsep would like to expand the types of food and household goods he sells.  He would like a loan to expand his store's products.  With this investment, Hovsep expects the shop income to increase by twenty-five percent.  He is planning and dreaming for all his children to attend university.  He likes living in Gyumri and looks forward to a bright future for his family.

loans.use: to purchase new products for the shop

loans.name: Primitivo

texts.es: El socio sigue trabajando prestando servicio de taxi a los clientes en la ciudad de Cusco, y con su trabajo el educa a sus hijos y les brinda todo tipo de comodidades, el socio desea ver a sus hijos profesionales y seguir teniendo fuerzas para trabajar. El socio solicita el prestamo para invertir en la compra de una llanta y en el mantenimiento de su vehiculo.
texts.en: The member continues providing taxi services to customers in the city of Cusco.  He is able to provide schooling and all sorts of comforts for his children.  He wants to see his children become professionals and he wants to continue to have strength to keep working.  He asks for the loan to buy a tire and to service his vehicle.

loans.use: to buy a tire and service the car.

loans.name: Wabukhonyi Shg Group

texts.en:
Dominic is the facilitator of the Wabukhonyi SHG group. Dominic and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Dominic takes care of eight children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to receive One Acre Fund’s best prices and to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Dominic had an excellent maize yield harvesting eight bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Dominic was only able to harvest 1½ bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Dominic and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Dominic will educate his children.

In 2012, the members of Wabukhonyi SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Dominic is pictured with his group members and the field officer is on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Tchossè Dénis

texts.fr: Tchossè Dénis est âgé de 33 ans et vit au Bénin. Tchossè Dénis est marié à une revendeuse du nom de Véronique. Tchossè Dénis a arrêté l'école au niveau primaire. Le couple a trois enfants dont certains scolarisés et tous à leur charge. En plus de leurs enfants, le couple a un autre enfant en charge. Les enfants vivent ensemble avec leurs parents. Le couple assure ensemble les diverses charges de la maison. Pour subvenir à ses besoins et à ceux de ses enfants, Tchossè Dénis exerce depuis sept ans le métier d’ajusteur. Grâce au revenu que lui génère cette activité, Tchossè Dénis contribue aux différentes dépenses de sa famille. Pour satisfaire aux besoins de sa clientèle de plus en plus grandissante, Tchossè Dénis sollicite pour une deuxième fois un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le crédit reçu antérieurement par Tchossè Dénis a été bien remboursé.
texts.en: Tchossè Dénis is 33 years old and lives in Benin. He is married to a market trader called Véronique. Tchossè Dénis left school after primary level. The couple has three children, some of whom attend school and all of whom are in their care. In addition to their children they look after another child. The children all live with their parents. The couple work together to see to the needs of their family. In order to meet these needs, Tchossè Dénis has worked as a building fitter for seven years. The revenue that he generates from this enables him to meet his family's expenditures. In order to meet growing customer demand he is seeking a second loan from ALIDé. The previous loan was successfully repaid.

loans.use: to purchase building fitting materials (iron etc)

loans.name: Altansuvd

texts.en:
Altansuvd, 42, owns a small hotel locates in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia.  She has been in business for less than one year. 

Altansuvd is a doctor who works as a family physician in the hospital in Kherlen, a western boundary town of Mongolia.

She is planning to renovate the rooms in her hotel to improve service and quality.  Her hotel has 10 rooms and its capacity is 20-25 guests per day.  On average, the daily per room cost is $15.  This is considered a very lower price.  

According her plan, Altansuvd can increase her room price by 5%-10%.  The loan will be dedicated to making renovations to her hotel rooms.

loans.use: to making renovations to her hotel rooms.

loans.name: Thorn's Group

texts.en:
Originally from a village in the Thmor Koul district, Thorn is a 51-year-old farmer who grows vegetables as a primary business to make her living. She has been with this business for more than three years and she supplements her income from her children who work for others. Thorn started taking loans from VisionFund three years ago. The previous loans from VisionFund have helped her to have a regular income and some savings for the future. Currently, she earns ten U.S. dollars per day. 

Thorn and the other two members in the group, who have been with VisionFund for three years and five years, are applying for another loan. She will use the entire loan to buy vegetables seeds and prepare land for her farm. She hopes to grow more vegetables and to earn more income to build on some savings so as to afford a bigger house in the future.

loans.use: to buy vegetables seeds and prepare land for her farm.

loans.name: Juana

texts.en:
Juana is a married woman from Trinidad, Bohol. She tills her own land to grow rice crops to sell. Farming is the main source of income of Juana’s family. Juana does her best to keep her farm productive.

Juana has requested a loan to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs. This loan will help Juana supply her farm of its needs.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers and other farm inputs.

loans.name: Fidaa

texts.en:
Fidaa is a 42 years old, married, and has six children who attend school. She has been working as a tailor from her home for the past 11 years. She is stylish and fashionable and seeks to please her customers as much as she can. 

Fidaa is requesting a loan for $1,600 Ameen s.a.l., which she will use to purchase a new tailoring machine in order to improve her business and increase her productivity. In the future, she plans to open her own tailoring shop and expand her business outside the country.

loans.use: to purchase a new tailoring machine.

loans.name: Danaya 1 Group

texts.fr:
Les membres du groupe Danaya 1 sont des femmes mariées  ayant une moyenne d’âge de 42 ans, 6 enfants et vivant dans des  familles traditionnelles élargie  à  Pourè, un des villages de San, 4ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles collaborent avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de mener à bien leurs activités agricoles pendant l’hivernage. 
Elles sont à leur deuxième prêt avec l’institution, les prêts passés ont été bien remboursés.
La spéculation cultivée est  l’arachide  avec     SANATA , debout au milieu  sur la photo.
Avec son prêt, elle compte acheter des intrants, des semences et payer les frais de labour pour entretenir  1,5 hectare. 
La production sera vendue au niveau du village et au marché de San, après la récolte, à une clientèle composée de revendeurs et de consommateurs. 
Elle compte réaliser un bénéfice moyen de 215.000FCFA par campagne.
Ce bénéfice lui permettra de payer son prêt et aussi d’aider son mari dans les dépenses quotidiennes.
texts.en:
The members of the group "Danaya 1" are married women averaging 42 years of age and six children each all living in traditional extended families in Pourè, a village in San (4th administrative region of the Republic of Mali). The women are collaborating with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso to carry out their farm work during the rainy season. They are on their second loan with the institution. The past loans have indeed been paid back.

The crop grown is peanuts, as is the case with SANATA, standing in the middle of the photo. With her loan, she intends to buy seeds and to cover the cost of plowing to maintain 1,5 hectares.

After the harvest, the produce will be sold in the village and at the San market to a customer base composed of retailers and consumers. 

She plans on making an average profit of  215,000 francs CFA per planting. This profit will enable her to repay the loan and also to help out her husband in covering day-to-day expenses.

loans.use: to cover the cost of plowing and to buy farm supplies and seeds

loans.name: San Antonio De Padua-San Salvador Group

texts.es:
Los socios pertenecen al banco comunal “SAN ANTONIO DE PADUA-SAN SALVADOR”; Este banco se ubicada en el distrito de San Salvador, perteneciente a la provincia de Calca y departamento de Cusco.
La socia es la Sra. Laureana, la socia continua dedicándose al negocio de tienda de abarrotes, la socia agradece a quienes forman parte de este sueño mediante este medio y se compromete a cumplir con el pago de sus cuotas en el plazo establecido, la socia continua vendiendo  productos de primera necesidad como arroz, azúcar, leche y aceite, la socia es una persona responsable y empeñosa, siendo de esta manera que la socia saca adelante a su familia.
La socia solicita el crédito para comprar leche, arroz, aceite entre otros.
Los otros socios se dedican al negocio de venta de carne, negocio de venta de crianza de animales, negocio de tienda de abarrotes y negocio de confección de ropas.
texts.en:
The members belong to the Communal Bank “San Antonio de Padua – San Salvador”. This bank is located in the District of San Salvador in Calca Province, Department of Cusco.

Sra. Laureana is one of the members who continues to manage a grocery business. She is grateful to those who have helped to fulfill her dream in this manner, so she promises to complete her loan payments according to the established terms. Laureana continues to sell basic necessity products such as rice, sugar, milk, and oil. She is a responsible and industrious person who works in this manner so that her family can get ahead. Laureana is requesting a loan in order to buy milk, rice, oil, and other products.

The other members engage in businesses in which they sell meat, raise and sell animals, sell groceries, and produce clothes. The lady whose face is covered is not receiving this loan.

loans.use: to buy milk, rice, oil, and other products.

loans.name: Edna

texts.en:
Edna, 25, is married to Canicious and blessed with two children, aged four years and one month respectively. She has been selling foodstuffs in her shop for four years and earns a monthly income of 15,000 Kenyan shillings.

This is her first loan with VisionFund Kenya. She intends to buy more stock of sugar, wheat flour, rice, cooking oil and tissue paper to sell in her shop. She anticipates helping her husband with paying school fees for their children from her increased business profits. She dreams of having a big shop that can supply goods to the whole village.

loans.use: to purchase shop items to sell to her customers.

loans.name: Maria

texts.en:
Maria runs a small food stand where she sells all types of typical Ecuadorian dishes. Her daughter helped her start this business 2 years ago by buying Maria the small barbecue in the picture. Maria started off by selling just empanadas and shish kabobs, two of Ecuador’s more popular foods. She now has a large of variety of foods and dishes that she makes.

Her dream is to one day have a restaurant. She wants to make reparations to her home in order to be able to offer seating for her clients. The first step is to add pavement to her home and make a section for her customers.

Maria is 40 years old and has 4 children who are already grown up. One of her daughters still lives with her and helps her in the business. Her husband also contributes to the business when he is not working.

Mifex offers its clients microinsurance and access to business training and educational programs. For more information about microfinance, Ecuador, and our services, please visit www.mifex.org.

loans.use: Make reparations to her home so it may become a restaurant

loans.name: Lavalea

texts.en: Lavalea is from the village of Lalovaea, and is married with two children. She runs a canteen business which opens five school days a week. She sells water for 50 cents a cup, and 100-150 pieces of cake for $1 each, earning $150 a day. The money earned is used to buy other goods to be baked and sold at her business, to buy family food for the week and pay for other family expenses.

loans.use: To purchase 5 bags of flour.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy fresh fish and a cooler

loans.name: Ana Glora

texts.es:
I have been selling delicacies, or golosinas as we call them in my country, for three years. I sell pastries stuffed with chicken and beef, enchiladas and tacos. My store is in front of my house and thanks to God my neighbors and other people near my village buy my products. With this business I help my family and I help to pay for my children’s schooling. My goal is to increase my sales and open a store to sell my golosinas and right now I need your help to be able to continue my business this month.

Translated from Spanish by Alexandra Jaffe, Kiva volunteer

Hace tres años que tengo este negocio de venta de golosinas como lo llamamos en nuestro pais. el negocio es de venta de pastelitos de pollo y carne de res, enchiladas y tacos. Mi negocio lo tengo enfrente de mi casa, gracias a Dios mis vecinos me compran y otras personas cercanas a mi colonia. Con este negocio ayudo a mi familia y a mis hijos con gastos del colegio. mi meta es ingrementar mis ventas y poder hacer un lugar donde vender mis golosinas, ahora necesito que me ayuden para poder vender en este mes.

loans.use: To purchase meat, cabbage, corn, onions, green chili, etc.

loans.name: Maurelia

texts.es:
Maurelia has worked since she was a young girl. She has three school-age children and works hard to provide for them. When the family income wasn't enough to meet even their basic needs she took to selling candy on the streets of her hometown. Her dream is to be able to rent a small space and open a stand where she will feel safe and she can offer her customers a greater assortment of products. In order to achieve this she asking for a loan of $325 promising to repay the amount in 6 months. She eagerly awaits news that you have generously decided to help her fulfill this dream.

Translated by a Kiva volunteer.

Maurelia, ha trabajado desde muy pequeña y su empeño y dedicación han hecho que pueda obtener una cantidad pequeña de capital, para invertirlo en su pequeño negocio. Ella tiene a tres pequeños niños en etapa escolar y su iniciativa de trabajo se generó por la insuficiencia del ingreso familiar para cubrir los gastos de primera necesidad de su familia. Desempeña esta labor en las calles de su ciudad natal y su anhelo es alquilar un pequeño local para ofrecer sus servicios desde un establecimiento fijo, de esta manera se sentiría más segura y procuraría a sus clientes mayor variedad y cantidad de artículos. Por esta razón ella solicita un préstamo de 325 dólares con el compromiso de retornarlos en un lapso de 6 meses. Maurelia espera tu ayuda generosa para iniciar este proyecto.

loans.use: To rent a small space and open a stand selling sweets.

loans.name: Razia

texts.en: I  am Razia S.. I moved to Lahore with my parents from Pattoki, a small town, when I was only six. I am married and have five children. I make jewelry tassels and my husband operates a ready made garments business. He buys these garmernts from a nearby small factory and sells them to different shops in the city. The wedding season is around the corner and I need to buy ready made garments in a large quantity. I will be able to double my income from this business expansion. I will save the extra profits and in future I plan to start a small garments factory of my own. We need a loan.

loans.use: Buy garments in bulk.

loans.name: Sarwar

texts.en: I am a widow and a mother of nine children, five girls and four boys. I make traditional bracelets that the brides wear on their weddings. I have been making these bracelets for last twenty five years and now two of my sons also assist me in this business. I am requesting a loan of $350 so that I can expand my current business. With this loan I will buy the required raw materials in bulk. I hope that with this business expansion we will be able to earn higher profits this wedding season that is just around the corner.

loans.use: Expand bracelets business

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Mrs. Eunice I. is 34 years old, married with three children, and lives in Benin City. She is a fashion designer and also sells tailoring materials.

Mrs. I. is soliciting a loan amount of $450 to buy more tailoring materials. She had learned her business for two and a half years before she started her own business in 2005. She is a dedicated LAPO client.

loans.use: To buy more tailoring materials for sale

loans.name: Sutianah

texts.en: Sutianah, 39, has five children. She runs a small shop from home where she sells snacks, flavored ices, etc., earning $15 a day. Her husband, S., works as security guard and earns $60 a month. She is asking for a loan of $125 to expand her business. She is a member of MBK and agrees to repay this loan within 12 months.

loans.use: To increase inventory in her food shop

loans.name: Angela María

texts.en:
Angela María is in her late fifties, and she lives in the area of Alcaviejo, Los Alcarrizos in the city of Santo Domingo. She has one twenty-year-old son. “I am married to the Lord,” she says to explain that she separated from her husband a couple of years ago, and that she had to raise her son on her own.

Angela owns and operates a clothing store which people visit every day to purchase new and used shirts, skirts, pants, shoes and other goods. She’s been running her store for three years in a small rented locale. She explains that she’d like to have a more spacious locale and more funds to invest in her business in order to move her business forward and increase her revenue.

Angela stresses the importance of good education, and says she’ll keep working hard to cover her educational expenses (she’s finishing last year of college) and support her son’s university studies.

loans.use: Purchase of clothing in bulk to increase her inventory.

loans.name: Le Thi

texts.en:
Mrs. Le Thi H. is 45 years old and joined the TYM Fund in 2003. She lives with her husband and has 2 grown up children. The family's main business is raising egg-laying ducks and fish for selling. Their average monthly income is $250.

To increase her income, Mrs. Le Thi H. now wishes to borrow $1,000 to buy eggs and food for her ducks. She hopes that with this amount she will be able to expand her business.

loans.use: Invest in animals sales

loans.name: Evelyn

texts.en:
Evelyn is thirty two years old and she has four children. All of the children are in school. Evelyn has been operating a grocery store in her community for ten years. Her operation has become the source of her family's income. She wants to use her loan to increase her inventory and avoid price hikes in the products. She believes this loan will help her to save for the children’s education.

Evelyn is a member of the group called "Commitment." Members agree in principle to guarantee for each other as social collateral to repay the loan.

loans.use: To buy more grocery products, such as vegetable oils, tin fish, canned milk, and oats

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Purchase of clothing in bulk to sell in her community.

loans.name: Nuon

texts.en:
Nuon O., 55, is a widow who lives in Prey Veng with her one child. She sells vegetables out of her home and typically makes US$ 2 each day. Inflation has been a very difficult problem for Cambodians and inconsistent weather patterns have recently hurt farmers.

NO. O. has asked for a loan of US$1000 to purchase a water pump to irrigate her farmland. This will help both with crop production and quality. With any leftover monies, she would like to purchase some fertilizer and gasoline to help with her family’s expenses. She believes this opportunity will allow her to increase her income and looks forward to reaping the benefits of this investment.

loans.use: Purchase water pump; fertilizer; gasoline

loans.name: Stanislav

texts.en:
Stanislav is married with a 12-year-old daughter. He is a businessman from Ivano-Frankivsk. Stanislav offers transportation services on the territory of Ukraine. He has been in the business for five years. His daily income is about $30-40.

Stanislav is seeking a loan of 3000 Grivnas to do some repair work on a car he rents and uses to work as a taxi driver. His business is the only source of income for the family. Stanislav served in the military before and is used to discipline and strategizing. We believes focus and determination will help him achieve his current goals and grow his business as a result. Stanislav is hoping to use a portion of generated profit to pay his daughter's college fees.

loans.use: Stanislav would like to do some repair work on his vehicle for his taxi business.

loans.name: Art

texts.en:
Art S., 28, is married with three children and lives in Kampong Cham province, Cambodia. Since 2008, she has been raising pigs to earn a living and is able to make about US$2 of profit per day. 

Her husband is a taxi driver (Phnom Penh- Kampong Cham). Normally, he makes around US$3 of profit per day. Her husband states some problems that he faces in running his business such as: the gas has skyrocketed and passengers have no will to pay more even though they know the gas price is high. That is why he makes less profit to support the family. 

Mrs. Art is asking for a loan to add to her livestock.

loans.use: To expand her livestock, raising pigs.

loans.name: Titilayo

texts.en:
Titilayo A. is 24 years old and she is married with two children. She lives in Issashi in Lagos State, Nigeria. She sells provisions and foodstuffs, like rice, beans, and plantain, in her shop.

Titilayo is a LAPO Microfinance client. She is requesting a loan of $1200 to buy more provisions and foodstuffs to sell. She is very grateful to all Kiva lenders and LAPO.

loans.use: To buy more provisions and foodstuffs to sell.

loans.name: Zaina

texts.en:
Zaina has been preparing and selling food in Zanzibar for 3 years. Her most popular food item is called "vitambua," which is eaten for breakfast or as a snack throughout the day. Vitambua is made of rice flour and cooked in oil in a pan with small round indents. The pan is kept over coals, and as the vitambua batter cooks, Zaina flips each one so that the finished product is a round, slightly browned starchy snack.

Zaina has previously taken out 1 loan from BRAC Tanzania, which she paid back successfully and on time. She is currently able to earn a profit of approximately $60 each month, and she is hoping that this second loan allows her to cook and sell more and increase her profit.

Zaina is 36 years old, married, and has no children.

loans.use: To buy more ingredients, like oil and flour, for the foods she prepares and sells

loans.name: Luz En La Tiniebla Group

texts.en: Maria K. is the representative of this group called "luz en la tiniebla".  She was chosen because she is a very hardworK. lady and is a perfect example of the type of person microcredit tries to work with.  She is living in extreme poverty and trying to provide for her five young children.  Each child is under the age of 16, and she even has a baby of nine months to care for.  She realized that she wanted to be able to provide a good life for her children and hopefully get them out of their poverty.  She is taK. out a loan to try and make this dream a reality.  She wants to start a small business maK. and selling clothing in her neighborhood.  She dreams of increasing her business into a thriving clothing store.  Her dream in life is to send all her children to college and have them be able to live out their dreams.  She is very excited about this first step to a better life and is ready for the challenge!

loans.use: To start a business selling clothing.

loans.name: Rukiya

texts.en: Rukiya N. is 45 years old and is married to a retired government employee. They have 3 children. Rukiya sells cereals like groundnuts, beans, peas, and rice in the Nakasero market in Kampala. She purchases her stock directly from upcountry farmers at a fair price, which enables her earn a good profit. She will use the loan to purchase more stock of cereals to meet the rising customer demand and also to hedge against the speculated rise in the purchase price of cereals. This hardworking lady owns a residential house of her own and she hopes that the increased income from her business will enable her to raise poultry in her home within the coming year.

loans.use: Purchase more stock of cereals .

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.vi: Chị Nguyễn Thị Lựu, 28 tuổi ở Quảng Xương Thanh Hoá. Gia đình chị có 2 con còn nhỏ. Chị  tham gia Quỹ tình thương từ năm  2003 và vay vốn để đầu tư vào dệt chiếu và nuôi hải sản. Hiện tại đây cũng là công việc đem lại nguồn thu nhập chính cho gia đình chị với thu nhập  3.000.000đ/ tháng. Vòng vốn tới anh chị muốn vay 9.000.000 để mua thêm nguyên liệu phục vụ cho công việc dệt chiếu của gia đình
texts.en:
Mrs. Nguyễn Thị Lựu, 28 years old, has two young children and lives in Quảng Xương district, Thanh Hoá province. She has participated in the TYM Fund since 2003, and has used her loans to invest in weaving straw mats and aquaculture. Currently, these activities are the main sources of income for her family, bringing in about 3,000,000 VND (175 USD) per month. In the next lending cycle, she hopes to borrow 9,000,000 VND (525 USD) to buy more raw materials for the family business producing straw mats.

Translated from Vietnamese by Robert Sides, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Weaving straw mats

loans.name: Comfort

texts.en:
Comfort A. is married and has 2 children. She has received schooling through primary education. Comfort sells groceries and other food supplies at Jukia near Cape Coast, which she has done since 1974. Her husband is a farmer.

Comfort uses her income to help her husband pay rent, utility bills and other basic expenses of the family. Comfort will use the loan to purchase more groceries and bags of rice, cartons of cooking oil, and other food items to meet the increase in demand by her customers. With the new profits from her expanded business, Comfort plans to reinvest for the expansion of her sales of groceries and other food items.

loans.use: purchase more groceries and bags of rice, etc. for re-sale

loans.name: Shahnaz Sabir Masih Group

texts.en:
Shahnaz baji is a 30-year-old married woman and a citizen of Borewala, Pakistan for the past 12 years. Her husband's name is S. M., and he is a mason by profession. Shahnaz baji is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. None of her children go to school. Shahnaz baji wants to send her children to school but due to her few financial resources she cannot do this. Her husband’s income is very low, so she shares the financial burden by knitting clothes. She successfully repaid two loans from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan). Now she is applying for a loan for her husband, because her husband wants to start a business selling animals. 

She is the group leader of more women in her area. Sajida parveen baji would like a loan to buy a donkey cart for loading. Jamila baji would like a loan to buy a sewing machine for sewing clothes. Gulnaz akhtar baji would like a loan to buy animals for her business selling animals. 

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To buy animals (goats) to sell

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To buy bags and jewelry for resale

loans.name: Enaam

texts.en: Enaam is a 37-year-old woman, living in Al Shwaifat in Mount Lebanon. She has been working as a home-based tailor for seven years. Today, she wants to borrow US$ 1,200 in order to buy a new sewing machine and some textiles.

loans.use: buy a new sewing machine and some textiles

loans.name: Gladiz Amanda

texts.es: La  Sra. Gladiz  tiene su negocio de venta de Mercaderia varias como ser, ropa para dama, caballeros y niños, sandalias , perfumes, cremas , desodorantes. Desde hace cuatro años, ella viaja dos veces al mes a vender al Departamento de la Paz, donde ya tiene clientes fijos, la señora cuenta tambien con la ayuda de su esposo el que trabaja como Guardia de Seguridad, ellos tiene  tres hijos los cuales dos de ellos estudian, su otra hija tiene problemas de salud ya que hace un tiempo le detectaron una enfermedad llamada leucemia, y ella tiene que llevarla dos veces al hospital para recibir atencion medica y esto le genera gastos semanales de L.500.00, con los ingresos que recibe por las ventas ella ayuda al sustento de su familia, necesita el dinero para poder comprar mercaderia al por mayor a precio mas bajo y con esto obtener mayores ingresos.
texts.en:
Mrs. Gladiz has a business in the sale of various merchandise such as clothing for ladies, gentlemen and children, sandals, perfume, lotions, and deodorant. For 4 months, she has traveled two times a month to sell in the Department of La Pas, where she has steady customers. Mrs. Gladiz does the accounting as well, with the help of her husband who works as a security guard. They have three children, two of which are studying, and their other daughter has health problems seeing that some time back the illness called leukemia was detected, and she had to be taken two times to the hospital to receive medical attention and this generated final expenses of L. 500.00. With the profits that she receives from her sales, Mrs. Gladiz helps in the subsistence of her family. She needs merchandise so she can buy better merchandise for a lower price and with this she can obtain better profits.

Translated from Spanish by Donna Yates, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To buy clothing, sandals, lingerie and lotions

loans.name: Victoria

texts.es:
La señora Victoria perteneciente al Banco Comunal “Rio Desaguadero” del distrito de Desaguadero, Provincia de Chucuito, Departamento de Puno; de estado civil conviviente; de 31 años de edad, con 2 hijos, posee estudios de secundaria completa. 
Trabaja con el Movimiento Manuela Ramos 1/2 año.  Inicio su negocio con un préstamo de S/. 500.00 soles, monto que invirtió en la comercialización de “Salchipapas” (comida al paso), venta de abarrotes al menudeo y bebidas de consumo masivo (cerveza) puesto que según referencia de la señora, esta última actividad le brinda mejores ingresos. 
Actualmente ella pretende mantener su negocio de bebidas (Gaseosas descártales, agua mineral) para lo cual requiere un préstamo de S/. 800.00 nuevos soles, con ello adquirirá mas mercadería para que lo comercialice en las ferias y eventos sociales para poder generar sus ingresos, ayudar a la economía familiar y pagar oportunamente sus cuotas programadas.  Finalmente agradece a la institución por el apoyo brindado a las mujeres hasta la fecha.
texts.en:
Victoria is a member of the "Rio Desaguadero" community bank of the district of Desaguadero in the province of Chucuito, department of Puno. She is married common-law, is 31 years old and has two children. She graduated from high school. She has been working with Movimiento Manuela Ramos for half a year. She started her business with a 500 soles loan which she invested in the sale of "salchipapas" (street food), selling groceries retail and large-scale sales of drinks (beer) which according to Victoria is her most important source of income. Currently, she wants to maintain her drink-selling business (soft drinks, mineral water) for which she needs a loan of 800 soles in order to sell at the market and at social events in order to generate more income and help her family's finances and pay her loan instalments on schedule. Also, she is grateful to the institution for its support of women.

Translated from Spanish by Laure Kwon, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: to buy soft drinks and mineral water

loans.name: Selestina

texts.en:
Selestina has been a clothes seller in the Kola neighborhood of Morogoro for 20 years. She belongs to Tupendane group loan (Group code 2001/2).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of approximately  $530. Every day she works at her business for 12 hours.  

She is requesting her third loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more clothes for resale. She is hoping that through this loan, her profit will increase and she will be able to increase her business.

Selestina is 45 years old, married, and has five  children: aged 27, 25, 20, 16, 8 and 7. She also cares for two dependents.

loans.use: To buy more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Emmanuel's Group

texts.en: B. Emmanuel is a friendly, hard-working man with a boda boda “motorcycle” business. With the help of loans, he has been able to own his current motorcycle and this helps to bring in more income and profits. He hopes to buy tubes and shock absorbers, once he gets a new loan, so that his customers are more comfortable on the bike. He is also a farm with banana, potato and cassava plantations. This endeavor also helps to bring in an extra income, although the farm is mostly managed by his wife and employed labor. He is the father of 5 children, of which 3 are in school while the other 2 are still young.

loans.use: Buying motorcycle spare parts.

loans.name: Leyla

texts.en: Leyla A. has been selling a big variety of cosmetic and home products in her store for the past eight years. She is married and has two adorable daughters. A true entrepreneur, she studies the market to determine client needs and preferences. Industrious and enterprising, Leyla is focused on expanding her business. Leyla is currently seeking a loan for 2000 USD. She plans to use the loan to increase her assortment of cosmetics and expand her business. With the increased sales and profits, Leyla hopes to expand her grocery and improve the living standards of her family.

loans.use: Increase her assortment of cosmetics

loans.name: Reynaldo

texts.en:
Reynaldo D. is a farmer. He is married but has no children yet. He wants to focus more on his business. All he wants to do is to buy another farm, but before he does that, he will make sure that he will have an abundant harvest from his existing farm.

For now, he needs additional capital for his business. He would like a loan of 7,000 PHP from CEVI. He will use the loan to buy fertilizers and farm chemicals. He is attending the CEVI cluster meetings. He has received not just loans, but education in running a business as well .

loans.use: To buy complete fertiliizers and farm chemicals

loans.name: Candida

texts.es:
Candida C. C. es una señora de 68 años de edad, quien vive con su esposo,  en una pequeña comunidad rural de Costa Rica llamada La Esperanza localizada en San José de Upala, Provincia de Alajuela. Ahí se desarrollan actividades como el comercio, ganadería de doble propósito (carne y le che) y agricultura. 

Doña Candida se dedica a la agricultura, específicamente a la siembra de platano. Dice que el mercado para este producto es muy bueno. Comenta que gracias a este proyecto sus condiciones de vida han mejorado considerablemente y dice además que ha crecido como persona y ha adquirido mucho conocimiento, dice que se siente muy capaz y muy feliz de poder mantenerse activa.

En estos momentos doña Candida desea obtener un microcrédito  por ¢685,000 (seiscientos ochenta y cinco mil colones), para darle mantenimiento a su cosecha además comprar fertilizantes, abonos entre otros insumos. Con esta inversión  espera lograr una buena cosecha, con un producto de características apropiadas para conseguir un precio de venta alto poder incrementar la producción. 

Doña Candida es socia de la Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Mujeres la Esperanza; la cual está integrada solo por mujeres, ya que se especializa en apoyar a mujeres no profesionales y  jefas de hogar, es una de las 100 organizaciones socias de EDESA en Costa Rica. Este será su cuarto préstamo y con él espera continuar creciendo a nivel personal y económico además de participar activamente en la organización de crédito en su comunidad.
texts.en:
Candida C. C. is 68 years old and lives with her husband in the small rural Costa Rican community of La Esperanza, located in San José of Upala, Alajuela Province. The main business activities for this area are cattle breeding (both meat and dairy) and agriculture. Doña Candida is a banana farmer. She says the demand for her product is very high. Thanks to her business, her living conditions have improved considerably and she has also grown as a person who has gained much knowledge through experience. Doña Candida is very happy that she can remain active. Doña Candida is currently requesting a microloan in the amount of 685,000 colones to pay for labor during the harvest season. She will also purchase fertilizers and other supplies. She hopes that this investment will result in a good harvest so that she can command a good price for her product. Doña Candida is a member of La Empresa de Crédito Comunal de Mujeres (the Women’s Communal Credit Union) in La Esperanza, which supports women entrepreneurs and heads of households. This institution is one of 100 member organizations of EDESA in Costa Rica. This is Doña Candida’s fourth loan and she hopes to continue growing personally and financially. She will also continue participating in the local credit organization in her community.

Translated from Spanish by Ronan Reodica, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase supplies & pay for labor to harvest bananas

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: To purchase cassava flour and silver fish for sale.

loans.name: Las Abejitas Group

texts.es: Las socias del grupo “Las Abejitas” están representadas por la señora Nely y conformada por 13 miembros los cuales se dedican a diferentes actividades como costurera D. prendas D. vestir, servicio D. peluquería, abarrotes en tienda D. barrio, transporte público D. pasajeros y a la venta D. productos como verduras, carne, detergentes, comida, Api, refrescos y diferentes materiales D. limpieza. La competencia dentro D. sus rubros es alta, pese a eso saben sacar adelante la actividad económica a la que se dedican. El crédito esta destinado al crecimiento D. sus negocios con la compra D. mercaderías, insumos y herramientas para mejorar más sus ingresos que les permitirá darles a sus familias una mejor calidad D. vida. En cuanto a la experiencia crediticia las socias van cursando su primer ciclo dentro D. la institución pero están contentos D. que se les brinD. un apoyo económico que ayudada a generar mejores ingresos y a mejorar la calidad D. vida D. su familia
texts.en:
